column1: White Plains is a city in Westchester County
column2: New York
column3: United States. An inner suburb of New York City
column4: it is the county seat and commercial hub of Westchester
column5: a densely populated suburban county that is home to approximately one million people. White Plains is located in south-central Westchester
column6: with its downtown (Mamaroneck Avenue) 25 miles (40 km) north of Midtown Manhattan.

column1: At the time of the Dutch settlement of Manhattan in the early 17th century
column2: the region had been used as farmland by the Weckquaeskeck tribe
column3: a Wappinger people
column4: and was called "Quarropas". To early traders it was known as "the White Plains"
column5: either from the groves of white balsam which are said to have covered it
column6: or from the heavy mist that local tradition suggests hovered over the swamplands near the Bronx River. The first non-native settlement came in November 1683
column7: when a party of Connecticut Puritans moved westward from an earlier settlement in Rye and bought about 4
column10: John Richbell of Mamaroneck claimed to have earlier title to much of the territory through his purchase of a far larger plot extending 20 miles (32 km) inland
column11: perhaps from a different tribe. The matter wasn't settled until 1721
column12: when a Royal Patent for White Plains was granted by King George II.In 1758
column13: White Plains became the seat of Westchester County when the colonial government for the county left West Chester
column14: which was located in what is now the northern part of the borough of the Bronx
column15: in New York City. The unincorporated village remained part of the Town of Rye until 1788 when the town of White Plains was created.On July 9
column17: a copy of the Declaration of Independence was delivered to the New York Provincial Congress
column18: which was meeting in the county courthouse. The delegates quickly adopted a resolution approving the Declaration
column19: thus declaring both the colony's independence and the formation of the State of New York. The Declaration itself was first publicly read from the steps of the courthouse on July 11.During September and October 1776
column20: troops led by George Washington took up positions in the hills of the village
column21: hotly pursued by the British under General Sir William Howe
column22: who attacked on October 28. The Battle of White Plains took place primarily on Chatterton Hill
column24:
and located just west of what was then a swamp but is now the downtown area) and the Bronx River. Howe's force of 4,000–6,000 British and Hessian soldiers required three attacks before the Continentals, numbering about 1,600 under the command of Generals Alexander McDougall and Israel Putnam, retreated, joining Washington's main force, which did not take part in the battle. Howe's forces had suffered 250 casualties, a severe loss, and he made no attempt to pursue the Continentals, whose casualties were about 125 dead and wounded. Three days after the battle Washington withdrew north of the village, this was then occupied by Howe's forces. But after several inconclusive skirmishes over the next week Howe withdrew on November 5, leaving White Plains to the Continentals. Ironically, one of Washington's subordinates, Major John Austin, who was probably drunk after having celebrated the enemy's withdrawal, reentered the village with his detachment and proceeded to burn it down. Although he was court-martialed and convicted for this action, he escaped punishment.The first United States Census, conducted in 1790, listed the White Plains population at 505, of whom 46 were slaves. (New York City's population at that time was about 33,000.) By 1800, the population stood at 575 and in 1830, 830. By 1870, 26 years after the arrival of the New York Central Railroad, it had swollen to 2,630 and by 1890 to 4,508. In the decades that followed the count grew to 7,899 (1900) and 26,425 (1910). White Plains was incorporated as a village in 1866 and as a city in 1916.


=== Modern history ===

Following World War II, White Plains' downtown area developed into what amounted to a destination" shopping district featuring branch stores of many famous New York-based department and specialty stores. Some of these retail locations were the first large-scale suburban stores built in the United States and ushered in the eventual post-war building boom. Construction of nearby parkways and expressways in the 1940s through the 1970s only enhanced White Plains' role as a retail location. With a city opening ceremony
column25: Macy's launched a grand White Plains store on Main Street across from City Hall in 1949. As the mayor said at the time
column26: this was a significant event in the life of White Plains. Other prestigious stores followed
column33: and a short-lived branch of Bergdorf Goodman

column41: the city of White Plains developed an extensive urban renewal plan for residential
column42: commercial and mixed-use redevelopment that effectively called for the demolition of its entire central business district from the Bronx River Parkway east to Mamaroneck Avenue. By 1978
column43: the urban renewal program centered around the construction of the Westchester County Courthouse (1974)

column46: and a number of other office towers
column47: retail centers and smaller commercial buildings.At the time of its construction

column49: and east to Hartford.Beginning in the 1950s

column1: White Plains has a humid subtropical climate
column2: with four distinct seasons. Winter is cold and wet
column3: with occasional snow and an average January temperature of 32.2 °F (0.1 °C)
column4: and summer is hot and relatively dry
column5: with a mean July temperature of 76.1 °F (24.5 °C). In spring and fall
column6: temperatures can fluctuate from cool to hot
column7: but are usually mild and comfortable. Precipitation is plentiful in all months of the year
column8: with somewhat of a relative dryness in summer. The city receives approximately 229 clear or partly cloudy days per annum
column9: with July typically being the sunniest month
column10: averaging more than 70 percent of possible sunshine.The lowest temperature ever recorded in White Plains since record-keeping began in 1948 was −3 °F (−19 °C) on January 19
column12: and the highest ever was 105 °F (41 °C) on July 6
column13: 2010. Over the course of a typical year
column14: there are 18 days of at least 90 °F (32 °C) temperatures
column15: and 7 days where temperatures do not rise above the freezing point.

column1: Westchester County Airport is located in Harrison

column3: which offer regularly scheduled flights to several destinations in Florida. In addition
